bibl.title: Letter, Southgate Cregmile in Chattanooga, Tenn. to Crittenden Cregmile, 1863, February 14
bibl.note: 1863 February 14 Southgate Cregmille in Chattanooga, Tenn., to his brother Crittenden. Assures him that all the recruits from their hometown are well. Mentions the weather and how it always begins to rain when they receive their marching orders. Has no idea where he will be the next time he writes. Concludes the reason for being paid more often is that the rail cars are getting through from Knoxville. Hopes the fact that hundreds of Rebel Gen. Braxton Bragg's men are deserting means that soon he will be caught.

div.p: I now seat my self to rite you a few lines to let you know what is going on here.
well in the first place all the Reily Boys are well.

the weather hase been very warm and dry here for nearly one month but our Division has marching orders for to march in the morning for some place I doent no where and to day it has commenced raining as it allwais does when we start on a march and no telling when it will stop.
the cars runs through from Chattanooga to Knoxville.
well Crit I will halft to stop riting for to day
so the next time you rite to me I exspect to be in Knoxville & Atlantia or some place else. I cant tell where.
Deserters from Bragg army are still coming in here by the hundred and if we get him stastba a gain the most of the will give them retuas up
